review_title: Be cautious when accepting a job here - be sure the department culture is good
pros: You can find some great people to work with, ERGs are great and benefits are pretty great.
cons:
CAUTION: Be sure to check and ask about the culture of the department and school before you accept. 
My school and department is a joke. The leadership is terrible, dishonest, and useless. Employees having relationships and manipulating leadership. Abusive behavior from employees to employees, and C-level leadership, even when told, have done little to nothing. They sent over no counselors or therapists after some of us were and are being abused for over 11 years now. Literally, have mental breakdowns due to the abuse.
I just say, be sure to check and ask about the culture of the department and school you are entering. Also, terrible pay with just more and more duties. No place is perfect, but you can at least go to work without being bullied by other employees while your leadership enables it.
UTD has the potential to be a great place to work, but C-level leadership and Deans do nothing for the worker bees, the people who keep the school running.

review_title: Amazing research university for mechanics and materials!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Richardson, TX
pros:
Note: My review is biased towards the coursework, research and faculty for Solid Mechanics / Mechanics of Materials.

Top class facilities for research.
Fully equipped laboratories comparable to most high ranked universities.

Amazing professors with very deep knowledge in their subjects and research areas.

Research directions are very interesting and varied amongst different groups.

Professors are supportive and are open to make time discuss matters outside coursework and research.

There are plenty of opportunities to get involved and apply the knowledge if you're in a research program/Ph.D.

My suggestion would be to make sure to get involved in some research to get the best experience at UT Dallas, even if it is as a research volunteer.

Would strongly recommend if you are inclined towards Solid Mechanics / Mechanics of Materials. (Subjects like Fracture & Fatigue, Computational Mechanics, Experimental Mechanics,Elasticity, Mechanical Behavior of materials etc. to name a few.)

Strong industry collaboration with companies in the DFW area.

University is relatively young and growing very fast!
cons:
Coursework tends to be more theoretical than applied, so it may not be best suited for a coursework masters unless you are self-motivated to work on open ended problems and skill up with the necessary skills for the jobs you are interested in.

They do not offer Research Assistantships for master's students, so please apply for the Ph.D if you are looking for funding or support.

University is very academically focused, with little to do outside research and coursework.

review_title: ("Simple and clean is the way that") you'll feel on the job
pros:
- It's a fairly easy job with very little barrier of entry. If you can smile and can handle basic human interaction in a friendly manner, you'll be perfectly fine.

- Low stress overall (except during Move-in / out season and night time work)

- Bosses are flexible and will work with your school schedule to make everything work. Worst comes to worst, trading shifts with your coworkers is fairly easy and usually someone can help out.
cons:
- Nighttime hours will run the unprepared ragged. 3am - 8am shifts will be the bane of your starting experience if you're not careful.

- You will have to be flexible: traditionally the job is understaffed so work shifts are sometimes not optimal for workers since all shifts have to be covered by somebody.

- Be cognizant of rule changes depending on the events happening in the dorms, sometimes what you're told is not up to date or is not consistent with other departments.

- THIS IS NOT A JOB FOR PEOPLE THINKING ABOUT UPWARD MOBILITY. THIS IS JUST A TEMPORARY STOP IF YOU NEED WORK UNTIL YOU FIND BETTER OPPROTUNITY ELSEWHERE.

pros: The professional staff you would work under (at the student union, where I worked) were nothing but helpful, to a point where you have to wonder how they could be so selfless. The students you work alongside are literally from all over the world, so there will always be an opportunity to expose yourself to different things and experiences you might not have been around otherwise. The scheduling process is perfect for student workers, and is based entirely around your availability. You create your own schedule and can work as much as you would like.
cons: The job is a service job, and as such, there are going to be people who treat you with little regard, sometimes even professors! The job has a number of tasks that are anything but fun, and more often than not will leave you disappointed in your fellow students (bathroom rounds will haunt you for the rest of your life). The only way to find covers for your shift is to directly communicate with you coworkers to see if theyd cover for you, which more often than not, they will not. It is very important to create a schedule that you love, because any deviation is going to be very tough for you.

review_title: An Excellent Choice of Employment for Students
pros: Working as a supervisor within University Recreations for UT Dallas has been a growing experience for me as student worker and taught me a fair amount of professional skills than I can transfer to future positions. Some of the major pros of working here are the interpersonal connections I made, it allowed me to expand upon my social and customer service skills as well. Additionally the hours I worked were created around my academic schedule as to avoid significant conflicts. The work environment is very friendly and all the staff are amicable towards each other and the patrons. The professional staff are connected closely with the student workers as well, and promotes a sense of camaraderie among all of us. Students will start out at staff, but the opportunity to become a supervisor is available to all once applications roll out.
cons: One of the cons include disrespectful patrons that do not adhere to the facilities policies and disregard staff and supervisor who check them on their behavior. Another downside is the potential lack of stimulation during quiet, non-busy shifts, so it is highly recommended that one brings a book to read or homework to work on after their assigned tasks for the shift are completed.

review_title: Abusive company takes advantage of students.
pros: Obviously, working under this company provides some benefits. For most positions, housing is offered near work, and the University provides a safe, friendly work environment in offices.
cons: Though free housing is offered, it is at the massive expense of pay and benefits. Management has little to no actual interaction with lower level employees, nor do they connect well with layers above them. Policy is haphazard, enforced at times, unenforced at others, and often made up on the spot to deal with current issues. Hiring is worse, the company seems to specifically pick out employees for hiring who will have no choice once hired but to stay, no matter what abuse they are forced to endure. This is largely because employment is at will, even for management, so firing and subsequent eviction can happen at a moment's notice. The employees hired often barely speak English, a critical component for communicating with and managing the human resources, with which it is their explicit job to interact. The environment is toxic, abusive and ensnaring to young employees who are drawn by the allure of a seemingly convenient job at their university.

pros:
- Convenient since the peer tutoring center is located on the campus
- Teaching helps keep you fresh in your subject, and other tutors are usually willing to help you out with questions in their field if they have downtime
- Co-workers are all very personable (nearly a requirement to land the job) and you'll definitely make some friends in the workplace
- No stress about not being able to answer a student's question as you can always pull in another co-worker for assistance
- Very relaxed work environment
- Absolutely fantastic boss
- Usually very easy to get shifts covered
cons: - Hours are capped. Weekly scheduled hours are capped at either 12 or 13 hours (can't quite remember which). You can cover the shifts of other people who teach your subject, but cannot exceed 19.5 total hours worked in the week.

review_title: I truly love my school and my job.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Richardson, TX
pros:
I am a graduate student research and teaching assistant. I can only speak for my department, but I have had the opportunity to work with brilliant researchers, inspiring lecturers, and professors who not only are knowledgeable and respected in their field, but also genuinely care about the success of their students. 

My supervisor and research mentor are flexible with my schedule, friendly, and fun to work with. I am challenged as a student and receive excellent quality, individualized instruction in my chosen discipline. 

Affordable, high quality university with top programs in the Behavioral and Brain Sciences.
cons:
Lack of benefits for student employees but I think that's the case at most college campuses. Low wages depending on department. 
This is minor when compared to quality of education but parking is a nightmare.

pros: UT Dallas is a very promising university. It is a relatively new public university in one of the fastest growing areas in the US. Even within my four-year stay, I have noticed significant signs of the growth of the university. Dallas is a nice city too with relatively less cost of living, compared to other big cities in the US
cons: Although the rank of UT Dallas is rising steadily, its current rank does not put it among the most elite ones. There are also several majors that are not offered at UT Dallas, making in it lack some diversity.

review_title: For students : Avoid it like a plague
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Richardson, TX
pros: Can't really think of one. Look at the Cons section and you will see. I am just filling out the 20 words minimum.
cons:
Payroll is a complete mess. They will mess up your paycheck, in my case multiple times. I wasn't paid collectively for 8 months over 3 periods where they messed up. Only after many emails and visits and involving the dean of the department was I able to resolve the issue 2 of the 3 times. 

Student worker/RA/TA salaries are a joke. They are some of the worst around if you compare with the Universities around Texas. In some cases I have seen its close to 50% of what others offer their students. You won't be able to manage the basic cost of living and the prices are going up like crazy. Not the salaries though.

review_title: A great place to learn and work as you finish up your degree!
pros: I worked for the Jindal School, and my coworkers were amazing. While I was the only student in the office, they were always very flexible with my classes, exams, and if I needed a day off. My job in the Dean's office was engaging, fun, and not beyond my level of difficulty.
cons: I learned that the politics of getting things done at a university in great deal. To make things happen it requires the sign off from so many people that you can feel bogged down by the requirements at times.

review_title: Fantastic student-worker position to have! (Looks good on resume, too!)
pros:
In this position, you experience a lot of self growth.
Mostly everyone is nice and easy to work with.
Your communication, teamwork, time management, and conflict resolution skills will skyrocket!
Monthly pay is only $168, but rent is free with no roommates and if you're in one the residence halls then you getting a free meal plan, too, so total compensation is very good.
cons: The two-week training period before classes start in August needs to be more hands on. I feel like it could be shortened by at least a few days this way. Training is still definitely a positive experience and they improve it every year, this was just the only thing I could think of.

review_title: Great understanding of what it takes to be an established scientist in a classified laboratory.
pros: Helpful faculty, great learning experience, great guidance and an ideal environment to put creativity and intelligence to work with supporting team members.
cons: Not very many at all, but If I must include, it would be that sometimes you might be expected to know and contribute more than you expect but that's what prepares student workers for their professional career ahead.

pros: The job is relatively easy if you are fit for the lifestyle. I viewed it as being paid to make friends. The housing and meal plan (along with a monthly paycheck) are great and definitely worth the time  invested.
cons: The position seems unnecessary for many students. Our residents are adults and usually just want to be left alone. I had to be pushy sometimes to get people to participate in activities and go out. I wish we didn't have to have minimum campus engagements and could just let people be.

Very few blacks and Hispanics in both the workforce and student population.

pros: Relatively flexible work environment, decent benefits, tuition discounts, great retirement if you stay long enough. Able to use facilities and athletic center (for a fee). Campus dining is easily accessible.
cons: No staff support, no promotional opportunities, little pay for lower level employees but very high output expectations. Inappropriate behavior is tolerated and accepted. I've seen so many FANTASTIC people come and go because they are run out by mismanagement and poor treatment. The people who have authority misuse their power and take advantage of employees. Doesn't help efficiency, provide a positive student experience or foster retention. Quite a disappointing experience personally and professionally.

review_title: Fantastic Pay, Great Location, Difficult Hours
pros: I loved the fact I was always within walking distance of work, due to the fact I was living on-campus at the time. The pay was also very good, considering similar positions I've seen from other universities.
cons: Unfortunately, the university placed a limit on working hours for students, which is great if you want to make sure that your employees aren't sacrificing themselves (and their grades) to work more hours, but at the same time, I would have loved to have had the chance to work a few extra shifts during lighter weeks when I didn't have a lot going on.

review_title: I have enjoyed my time and grown with the company.
pros: I love the benefits and being able to take off to tend to family. The work environment is clean and organized. I have met a lot of professionals. I live the flexible schedules and Christmas break. I love the people and the events.
cons: The pay is not enough to support a big family. I wish that they would pay more money for persons with college degrees. They should also offer free parking for staff. It's would be nice to get more on the job training.

review_title: If you fit in, you stay; If not, you go to SMU
job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in Richardson, TX
pros:
-- Good work/life balance: You won't have to drive to your job in the ice because they'll be closed. If your kids' school is closed, you probably get to stay home, too! The culture is very family-friendly (i.e., easy to accrue and use sick/vacation time) and generally a decent place to work if you are not worried about your wages.
-- Job Security: It's kind of difficult to get fired. If you are a good worker, the fact that "the boss" doesn't like you or one small blunder won't get you axed. 
-- Open Door Policy: Just about everyone is pretty accessible - from admins to directors to deans. 
-- Great Surroundings: The school is very competitive for a public school. Students really get a good education from this institution. The campus is beautiful.
cons:
-- EXTREMELY LOW pay and incredibly small raises
-- If the higher up(s) like you, you get promoted/raises/opportunities for growth; otherwise, limited opportunities for movement
-- A lot of internal jobs or jobs that are already filled are posted on the UTD jobs website, so you may be applying to something that is just on there because policy requires them to post it - so growth is limited if you're not BFFs with higher ups
-- While the atmosphere is generally nice and laid back, the pay drives good people to other institutions, namely SMU
-- Can be frustrating to get great feedback from immediate supervisor but slim raises because s/he is not the one in charge of giving the raises.
-- If you don't have Orange or Purple parking stickers (which are nearly two hundred and four hundred dollars), parking can be a pain. However, this is the case with most college campuses.

pros: It was an awesome place to learn and I loved everyone that I worked with. There were world class professors and i was happy there. I would highly recommend attending UT Dallas who wants to learn at a competitive and world-class university with out having to pay private school prices.
cons: Construction was one of the major cons that I can think of. I wish they had a football team. They did not have much housing for upperclassmen and this was a problem. Chartwells and University Village had a monopoly on the food and housing of the students and this not good.

pros: As a writing center employee, I get to help students improve their writing. It's a great experience for future teachers and all the other tutors are great people. Everyone is super friendly and willing to help you out if you have a tough issue to tackle with the students.
cons: As a student worker position, the hours are limited. It's tough to share a limited number of hours with many other tutors, but scheduling is pretty fair.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: This institution is a fun place to work. The general layout of everything (building, trees, parking) makes the institution a conducive environment for teaching and learning. UT Dallas is growing in leaps an bounds.
cons: There is really no downside working for UT Dallas. The only one that comes to mind now is that the institution seems to be over admitting these days. Sometimes the campus feels a little over crowded. Scholarship and funding are limited.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Richardson, TX
pros:
Good benefits if you like to constantly go to school since employee rates were very low hourly for tuition.
Most people were pleasant to work with.
Gym is great.
Student Union was great.
Pension and this is the only company I have ever worked with that had a true pension.
cons: Hand full of ego driven assistant and associate deans in the school I worked in made waking up for work painful to my soul.

pros: Vacation time, sick time, and holidays off.
cons:
In order to move in to a new department on campus, or move up, you need the "right" connections.  You have to know the "right" people to get anywhere here.  If you don't then don't plan on moving up or moving anywhere else on campus.  

Lots of problems with in office cliques.

The administration is not very good and doesn't value good staff.  

High stress jobs, low salaries.

review_title: Decent place to work as a student, be aware of subtle discrimination and other issues though.
pros: Student Workers are exempt from FICA (SS and Medicare) taxes, most employers are easy going and mindful of class obligations, no commuting for work, student co-workers are usually pretty easy to get along with. Beats retail/food service/etc. for work/life balance.
cons:
Low pay, low hours, favoritism, high turnover, raises are a joke ($1/hr), inexperienced student "supervisors" (I had to quote the FLSA to one of the students in charge that didn't want to pay my overtime that was a result of her miscommunication and mismanagement).

Sometimes, student workers have an attitude of student employment is "not a real job" and don't put forth the same effort you do, after a while that starts to wear down your own moral and drive.

If you're a non-FWS (Federal Work Study) American citizen, get used to being put behind FWS recipients and F-1 visa holders for on-campus jobs. FWS is cheap labor for the school (Feds cover 75% of wages). F-1 foreign students can't legally work anywhere else, so they get first dibs the few non-FWS on-campus jobs.

Employers sometimes forget that student employees are usually relying on income from that job. I had one employer cancel a week of work because she forgot to order the consumable supplies required for our job (it was the same one that needed a primer on the FLSA, BTW). Another employer told us that we would be rehired in the fall and didn't tell us that they didn't have the budget to hire us until well into the fall. That would've been nice to know during the summer so I could have found another job, and not spent 4 months unemployed under the impression I had a job come the fall.

pros: Extremely discounted tuition if you can find the time to take the classes.
cons:
No established University wide culture, each school makes up their own and there is no accountability. 

My father passed while I was working there and the day I came back to work I was told things like "You should be home, I would feel guilty if it was my father and I came back to work" and that my work would not be trusted while I was grieving. I asked to work from home a few hours a week so I was available to my family and they tried to make me stay home without pay instead. When I went to HR to keep them from making me stay home, they let me work from home one day a week for a month instead and then added the incident to my 6 month review as an attendance concern. A month later I was ambushed in my "one on one" weekly reviews by the director and was suddenly receiving weekly reviews with both my supervisor and the director without notice or explanation. At each review I was grilled over any single typo made on the web. It should be noted that there is no staging environment and no QA or review process. The weekly reviews were so harsh that I began to see a therapist to cope with reviews. They finally offered me the opportunity to quit before they terminated me for spelling mistakes. As they documented every single mistake, I can tell you there were less than 20 over the 10 month period. They were cruel and there was no one above them to hold them accountable for any management style. Their offer of termination was mercy and my therapist agrees. Ironically, I received my BA from this school years before and am still paying on the loans.
